unit_learning_outcomes.description: Use academic language appropriately to express ideas and arguments.
Employ and develop pedagogical strategies for promoting language and literacy development.
Apply knowledge of the relationship between oral language, adult–child interaction and literacy development.
Critically evaluate early childhood settings in terms of language and literacy development.
Use peer reviewed research to justify decision making.
Use appropriate metalanguage when analysing language structure and function.

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Weekly reading and associated online postings
Miscellaneous study skills (e.g. library workshop, iLearn training, academic writing workshops)

enrolment_rules.description: Admission to MTeach(0-5) and ECHX600 or ECEX600 or ECHX6000

assessments.description: Students choose an area of special interest in early childhood language and literacy development from a list of topics related to the content covered in the unit. 2000 words.

Students analyse an interaction between an adult and a child during shared reading of a picture book, select a picture book for that child and design a literacy learning experience for that child using the selected picture book. 2000 words.

assessments.assessment_title: Fostering infant-toddler language and literacy in ECEC settings
assessments.description: Drawing on research literature on language and literacy development in the infant and toddler years, students write a report with evidence-based recommendations for designing and evaluating the physical and interactional environment of infant-toddler rooms in ECEC settings in terms of its potential to promote language and literacy learning. 1500 words

Students observe a room for infants and/or toddlers in a long day care centre and evaluate its physical and interactional environment in terms of its potential to promote language and literacy learning. 2000 words.

data.subject_search_title: ECHX8230 - Language and Literacy in Early Childhood
data.description: This unit will explore what language is and how it develops in early childhood from birth to eight years of age. The relationship between language, learning and culture will be investigated. Students will consider different definitions of literacy and examine how oral language in the early years of life relates to subsequent knowledge of written, visual and aural texts. Issues to be addressed include how to create a language and literacy rich environment and the central role of adults in supporting children's language and literacy development in a range of contexts. All enrolment queries should be directed to Open Universities Australia (OUA): see www.open.edu.au
